docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurers, which used to pay for prescription drugs with little attention to price, are increasingly influencing Americans' choice of medicines. Trying to curb drug costs, the fastest-growing expense in many health plans, they are offering financial incentives to people who select a lower-price version of a medicine when a choice is available. The intervention in a decision that used to involve only the doctor and the patient is a big change in the way Americans buy medicine and follows similar efforts by insurers to influence patients' choices of doctors and hospitals. But some physicians are concerned that pressure to reduce the cost of drugs could conflict with the patient's best interest.

headline.main: Insurers Press Use of Cheaper Drugs

docs.lead_paragraph: The 14-hour days spent treating heroin addicts at a clinic in Warsaw leave Helena Baran exhausted. But after spending 10 hours here, listening to grim predictions about crack in Europe, she was alarmed. "This is all we need," she said as four American mayors finished giving their European counterparts a blunt lesson on drugs and urban decay at a meeting here this week. "We have unemployment, people on the margin. There's already a black market in opium and barbiturates. Now, with the borders open, this drug might well flow in."

headline.main: Drugs in Europe: Signs of a Spreading Plague

byline.original: By TOM MASHBERG, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke asked the County Board of Legislators for guidelines on drawing up his second $1 billion budget, this one for 1991, one of their suggestions was "to keep the increase under double digits," he said. And so he did, asking for a 9.36 percent increase in the county property tax. This seemed, at first glance, to be a considerable improvement over the 27 percent rise in tax-levy support that he had asked for the 1990 budget, a request that so shocked the Board that it slashed the increase to 17 percent before some of the cuts were restored.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Ethan Kalett states that an end to the drug war "would increase abuse and have little effect on crime" (letter, Oct. 22). But each day brings more evidence that adopting some form of drug decriminalization would enhance law and order while not necessarily leading to significantly more drug abuse over the long term.

headline.main: Eventually, We'll Have to Legalize Drugs

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time, researchers have found a specific brain abnormality that could explain why some children and adults are hyperactive and cannot pay attention or be still. Investigators at the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md., have found that adults who have been hyperactive since childhood had markedly low brain activity in areas that are used to control attention and movement. Hyperactivity is characterized by fidgetiness and an inability to concentrate or complete a task. The finding is being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine. A More Scientific Footing Psychiatrists said the result could put hyperactivity on a more scientific footing, showing that it is not a psychological problem but rather a specific neurological problem that is often inherited. About 25 percent of the parents of hyperactive children are themselves hyperactive.

headline.main: Researchers Say Brain Abnormality May Help to Explain Hyperactivity
